atqui: <entryFree id="n4276" type="main" key="atqui"><orth extent="full" lang="la">at-qui</orth> (in MSS. sometimes <orth extent="full" lang="la">adqui</orth>, e. g. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:3:5:8" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 3, 5, 8</bibl> Mai, and often confounded with atque), <sense id="n4276.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">conj.</hi> (the form atquin is incorrect and post-class.; for <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:4:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 3, 4, 55</bibl>, should be read <hi rend="ital">at quin</hi> separately, Fleck.; cf. Caper Orth. p. 2441) [qui, <case>abl.</case> of <hi rend="ital">indef.</hi> quis, used adverbially; so pr. <hi rend="ital">but anyhow;</hi> cf.: alioqui, ceteroqui]. </sense><sense id="n4276.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen., serving to connect-an adversative clause or assertion, <hi rend="ital">but anyhow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but any way</hi> or <hi rend="ital">wise</hi>, <hi rend="ital">yet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">notwithstanding</hi>, <hi rend="ital">however</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rather</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but now</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but nevertheless</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and yet</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">a)lla\ dh/, a)lla\ dh/pou, a)lla\ mh/n</foreign> (a purely adversative particle, a more emphatic <hi rend="ital">at</hi>, while atque is regularly copulative; v. atque; syn.: at, sed, verum, autem; comparatively rare in all periods, it being scarcely more than an emphasized form of at): <hi rend="ital">Th.</hi> Quid aïs, venefica? <hi rend="ital">Py.</hi> Atqui certo comperi, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 1, 9</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Sy.</hi> Gratiam habeo. <hi rend="ital">De.</hi> Atqui, Syre, Hoc verumst et re ipsā experiere propediem, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:5:5:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 5, 5, 7</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">Cl.</hi> Satis scite promittit tibi. <hi rend="ital">Sy.</hi> Atqui tu hanc jocari credis? <hi rend="ital">but yet do you believe that she is jesting?</hi> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:4:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 4, 4, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum omnia vi et armis egeris, accuses eum, qui se praesidio munierit, non ut te oppugnaret, sed ut vitam suam posset defendere? Atqui ne ex eo quidem tempore id egit Sestius, ut, etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>and yet</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:37:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 37, 79</bibl></cit>: tum, ut me Cotta vidit, peropportune, inquit, venis ... atqui mihi quoque videor, inquam, venisse, ut dicis, opportune, <hi rend="ital">rather I seem to myself</hi>, etc., <foreign lang="greek">a)lla\ mh\n kai\ e)moi\ dokw=</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:7:16" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 7, 16</bibl>: vitas hinnuleo me similis Chloe ... atqui non ego te tigris ut aspera Gaetulusve leo, frangere persequor, <hi rend="ital">but yet</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">a)lla/ toi</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:23:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 23, 1</bibl>-10: Jam vero videtis nihil esse tam morti simile quam somnum; <cit><quote lang="la">atqui dormientium animi maxime declarant divinitatem suam,</quote> <trans><tr>but yet</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:22:81" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 22, 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tum dixisse (Lysandrum), mirari se non modo diligentiam, sed etiam sollertiam ejus, a quo essent illa dimensa atque descripta: et ei Cyrum respondisse: Atqui (sc. ne putes alium id fecisse) ego omnia ista sum dimensus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 17, 59</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4276.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n4276.3" n="A" level="2"> In adding a thought confirmatory of a preceding<cb n="ATRA" />  one, but not antithetical (v. at <hi rend="ital">init.</hi>), <hi rend="ital">but indeed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but certainly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">by all means: Do.</hi> Salvos sis, adulescens <hi rend="ital">Sa.</hi> Siquidem hanc vendidero pretio suo. <hi rend="ital">To.</hi> Atqui aut hoc emptore vendes pulcre aut alio non potest, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:4:4:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 4, 4, 31</bibl>: Et Philus: praeclaram vero causam ad me defertis, cum me improbitatis patrocinium suscipere vultis. Atqui id tibi, inquit Laelius, verendum est, <hi rend="ital">but certainly</hi> (ironically), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:3:5:8" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 3, 5, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:1:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 1, 1, 4</bibl>.—Sometimes with <hi rend="ital">pol</hi> or <hi rend="ital">sic</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">atqui pol hodie non feres, ni genua confricantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:3:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 3, 3, 80</bibl></cit>: <hi rend="ital">Py.</hi> Scis eam civem hinc esse? <hi rend="ital">Pa.</hi> Nescio. <hi rend="ital">Py.</hi> Atqui sic inventast, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:4:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 4, 30</bibl>: hunc ego non diligam? non admirer? non omni ratione defendendum putem? Atqui sic a summis hominibus eruditissimis accepimus, etc., <hi rend="ital">yet so we have certainly heard</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:8:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Arch. 8, 18</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n4276.4" n="B" level="2"> So also atqui si, adversative, <hi rend="ital">but if</hi>, or continuative, <hi rend="ital">if now</hi>, <hi rend="ital">if indeed</hi> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">quod si): sine veniat. Atqui si illam digito attigerit, oculi illi ilico ecfodientur,</quote> <trans><tr>if</tr>, <tr>however</tr>, <tr>he do but touch her</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 4, 6, 1</bibl></cit> (Fleck., <hi rend="ital">Qui</hi>): quae et conscripta a multis sunt diligenter et sunt humiliora quam illa, quae a nobis exspectari puto. <hi rend="ital">Att.</hi> Atqui si quaeris ego quid exspectem, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:5:15" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 1, 5, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:23:62" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 4, 23, 62</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">atqui, si ita placet, inquit Antonius, trademus etiam,</quote> <trans><tr>well now</tr>, <tr>if</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:50:204" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 50, 204</bibl></cit>: atqui Si noles sanus, curres hydropicus, <hi rend="ital">but now if you are unwilling</hi>, etc., <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 33</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">atqui si tempus est ullum jure hominis necandi, quae multa sunt, certe illud est,</quote> <trans><tr>but if now there is any time</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:chapter=4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 4 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n4276.5" n="C" level="2"> To modify a preceding negation or negative interrogation, <hi rend="ital">yet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">still</hi>, <hi rend="ital">instead of that</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rather: Ni.</hi> Numquam auferes hinc aurum. <hi rend="ital">Ch.</hi> Atqui jam dabis, <hi rend="ital">but</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:7:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 7, 26</bibl>: Non sum apud me. <hi rend="ital">Se.</hi> Atqui opus est nunc quom maxime ut sis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:1:4:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 1, 4, 27</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">O rem, inquis, difficilem et inexplicabilem. Atqui explicanda est,</quote> <trans><tr>nevertheless</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 8, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 36, 114</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">magnum narras, vix credibile. Atqui Sic habet,</quote> <trans><tr>but in fact</tr>, <tr>so it is</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:9:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 9, 52</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:10:5" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 6, 10, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">modum statuarum haberi nullum placet? Atqui habeatur necesse est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 59</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 3, 86</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Parad. 1, 1, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:2:53" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 2, 53</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:10:10" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 6, 10, 10</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4276.6" n="D" level="2"> To connect a minor proposition in a syllogism (both an affirmative and a negative, while atque only connects an affirm. proposition), <hi rend="ital">but</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but now</hi>, <hi rend="ital">now</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ergo cum sol igneus sit, quia nullus ignis sine pastu aliquo possit permanere, necesse est aut ei similis sit igni, quem ... aut ei, qui ... atqui hic noster ignis etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:15:40" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 15, 40</bibl></cit> and 41: <cit><quote lang="la">qui fortis est, idem est fidens ... Qui autem est fidens, is profecto non extimescit ... Atqui in quem cadit aegritudo, in eundem timor ... Ita fit, ut fortitudini aegritudo repugnet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:7:14" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 7, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(mors) aut plane neglegenda est ... aut etiam optanda, si, etc. Atqui tertium certe nihil inveniri potest. Quid igitur timeam si, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:19:66" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 19, 66</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:14:40" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 5, 14, 40</bibl>. (Vid. more upon this word in Hand, Turs. I. pp. 513-524.)</sense></entryFree>
atracides: <entryFree id="n4277" type="main" key="A_^tra^ci^des"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^trăc-ĭdes, -is</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">-ius</orth>, v. Atrax.</entryFree>
atractylis: <entryFree id="n4278" type="greek" key="a^tracty^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ătractylis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)traktuli/s</foreign>, <sense id="n4278.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a thistle-like plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">woolly carthamus</hi>: Carthamus lanatus, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 15, 53, § 90</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:184" default="NO" valid="yes">21, 32, 107, § 184</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
atramentarium: <entryFree id="n4279" type="main" key="a_tra_menta_ri^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ātrāmentārĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>atramentum</etym>, <sense id="n4279.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an inkstand</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">atramentarium scriptoris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,053:9:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Ezech. 9, 2</bibl></cit> (as transl. of the Heb. <foreign />); 9, 3; 9, 11.</sense></entryFree>
atramentum: <entryFree id="n4280" type="main" key="a_tra_mentum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ātrāmentum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>ater</etym>, <sense id="n4280.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">any black liquid</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sepiae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N D. 2, 50, 127</bibl></cit>. </sense><sense id="n4280.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Writing-ink</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ink;</hi> in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 7, 10</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 7, 28, § 52</bibl>, called atramentum librarium: <cit><quote lang="la">calamo et atramento temperato,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> ad Q. Fr. 2, 15, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">per atramentum et calamum scribere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,025:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 3 Joan. 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 102, 13</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 236</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,049:36:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Jer. 36, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,024:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 2 Joan. 12</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4280.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A black pigment</hi> or <hi rend="ital">color</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 7, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7:4" default="NO" valid="yes">7, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 6, 25, § 41</bibl>; also <hi rend="ital">a fine</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dark varnish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lacquer</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:97" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 35, 10, 36, § 97</bibl>: Indicum, <hi rend="ital">India</hi> or <hi rend="ital">China ink</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 35, 6, 25, § 43</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4280.3" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A blacking for coloring leather</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">atramentum sutorium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:123" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 12, 32, § 123</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 21 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>—</sense><sense id="n4280.4" n="IV" level="1"> In comic language: <hi rend="ital">Sc.</hi> Unā operā ebur atramento candefacere postulas. <hi rend="ital">Phil.</hi> Lepide <cb n="ATRI" /> dictum de atramento atque ebore, i. e. <hi rend="ital">you require something impossible</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:3:102" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 1, 3, 102</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
atramitae: <entryFree id="n4281" type="main" key="A_^trami_tae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^tramītae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)adrami=tai</foreign>, <sense id="n4281.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people in the eastern part of Arabia Felix</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Hadramaut</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:154" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 28, 32, § 154</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:52" default="NO" valid="yes">12, 14, 30, § 52</bibl>; cf. Mann. Arab. 79.— Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^tramītĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">from the country of the Atramitœ</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Atramitic</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">myrrha,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 16, 35, § 69</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
atratus: <entryFree id="n4282" type="main" key="a_tra_tus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ātrātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, as if from atro, āre [ater], <sense id="n4282.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">clothed in black for mourning</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dressed in mourning</hi>: cedo, quis umquam cenārit atratus? * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,023:chapter=12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Vatin. 12 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">plebes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">senex,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:18" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Galb. 18</bibl></cit>.— <cit><quote lang="la">Also of suppliants: an atratus prodiret in publicum proque rostris precaretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:47" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 47</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg> of the horses in the chariot of the sun darkened in an eclipse: <cit><quote lang="la">Solis et atratis luxerit orbis equis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:4:34" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 4, 34</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:7:32" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 7, 32</bibl>: Et citius nigros sol agitabit equos).</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n4283" type="hapax" key="A_tra_tus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ātrātus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4283.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small river in the vicinity of Rome</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:43:98" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 43, 98</bibl> B. and K.</sense></entryFree>
atrax: <entryFree id="n4284" type="main" key="A_^trax"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^trax</orth>, <itype>ăcis</itype>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/atrac</foreign>. <sense id="n4284.0" n="I. A." level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Masc.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a river in Ætolia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 2, 3, § 6</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4284.1" n="B" level="2"> Derivv. </sense><sense id="n4284.2" n="1" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^trăces</orth>, <hi rend="ital">those living near the Atrax</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 2, 3, § 6</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4284.3" n="2" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^trā-cĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of Atrax</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Atracian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">oris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:8:25" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 1, 8, 25</bibl></cit> (Müll., <hi rend="ital">Antariis</hi>).—</sense><sense id="n4284.4" n="II. A." level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Fem.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a town in Thessaly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the Peneus</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Sidhiro-peliko</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 8, 15, § 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 32, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:36:10" default="NO" valid="yes">36, 10</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4284.5" n="B" level="2"> Derivv. </sense><sense id="n4284.6" n="1" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^tră-cĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">Atracian</hi>, <usg type="style">poet.</usg> for <hi rend="ital">Thessalian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ars,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>magic art</tr>, <tr>which the Thessalians practised much</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:1:105" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 1, 105</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">venenum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:6:447" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 6, 447</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4284.7" n="2" level="3"> (A patronymic instead of a gentile nom.; cf. Loers ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:17:248" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 17, 248</bibl>.) <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^trăcĭdes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the Thessalian Cœneus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:209" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 209</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4284.8" n="3" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^tră-cis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the Thessalian woman</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Hippodamia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:1:4:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 1, 4, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:17:248" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 17, 248</bibl>; called also Ātrăcĭa virgo in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:1:141" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 1, 141</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
atrebates: <entryFree id="n4285" type="main" key="Atre^ba^tes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Atrĕbătes</orth>, <itype>um</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)atre/batoi</foreign> Strab., <foreign lang="greek">*)atreba/tioi</foreign> Ptolem., <sense id="n4285.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people in</hi> Gallia Belgica, now <hi rend="ital">Artois</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Dép. du Pas de Calais</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 4</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 16</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 23</bibl>; 7, 75; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 17, 31, § 106</bibl>.—In <number>sing.</number>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Atrĕ-bas</orth>, <itype>ătis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">an Atrebatian</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:4:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 4, 35</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Atrĕbătĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Atrebatian</hi>: sagum, Treb. Gall. 6.</sense></entryFree>
atreus: <entryFree id="n4286" type="main" key="A_^treus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^treus</orth> (dissyl.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:5:24" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 5, 24</bibl>), <itype>ei</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)atreu/s</foreign>. <sense id="n4286.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A son of Pelops</hi> (hence, Pelopeïus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:8:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 8, 27</bibl>) <hi rend="ital">and Hippodamia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brother of Thyestes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">father of Agamemnon and Menelaus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">king of Argos and Mycenœ</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:855" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 855</bibl>.—Atrea (<case>acc.</case>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:3:12:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 3, 12, 39</bibl>.—Atreu (<case>voc.</case>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Thyest. 486" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Thyest. 486</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:513" default="NO">513</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4286.1" n="II" level="1"> Derivv. </sense><sense id="n4286.2" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^trēĭus</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^trēus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to Atreus</hi>, <usg type="style">poet.</usg> for <hi rend="ital">Argive</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:8:743" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 8, 743</bibl>; cf. Pompei. Gram. p. 113 Lind.—</sense><sense id="n4286.3" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^trīdes</orth> (Atridă in <case>nom.</case>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:14:1" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 14, 1</bibl>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a male descendant of Atreus; Atrides</hi>, <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> usu. for <hi rend="ital">Agamemnon;</hi> in <number>plur.</number>: Atridae, <hi rend="ital">the Atrides</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Agamemnon and Menelaus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:9:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 9, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">non minor Atrides, non bello major et aevo,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>not Menelaus</tr>, <tr>not Agamemnon</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:623" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 623</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:13:359" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 13, 359</bibl>; 15, 162.—In <case>dat.</case> and <hi rend="ital">abl. plur.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Atridis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:203" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 3, 203</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:1:7:32" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 1, 7, 32</bibl>.—In <hi rend="ital">acc. plur.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Atridas superbos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:10:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 10, 13</bibl></cit>.—In <number>sing.</number>, </sense><sense id="n4286.4" n="(a)" level="5"> For <hi rend="ital">Agamemnon</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:6:23" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 6, 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:4:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 4, 7</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:187" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 2, 3, 187</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:189" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 189</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">13, 230</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">13, 365</bibl>; 13, 439; 13, 655 et saep.— </sense><sense id="n4286.5" n="(b)" level="5"> For <hi rend="ital">Menelaus</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 7, 43</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:805" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 805</bibl>.—Sarcastically: <cit><quote lang="la">Atrides, of Domitian, as a haughty ruler of Rome,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:4:65" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 4, 65</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
atriarius: <entryFree id="n4287" type="main" key="atri^a_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">atrĭārĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>atrium</etym>, <sense id="n4287.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a porter</hi>, <hi rend="ital">door-keeper</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:4:9:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 4, 9, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:7:1:15" default="NO">7, 1, 15</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
atricapilla: <entryFree id="n4288" type="gloss" key="atri^ca^pilla"><orth extent="full" lang="la">atrĭcăpilla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>atricapillus</etym>, <sense id="n4288.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a bird of black plumage</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the blackcap</hi>, Paul. ex Fest. s. v. melancoryphi, p. 124 Müll.</sense></entryFree>
atricapillus: <entryFree id="n4289" type="gloss" key="atrica^pillus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">atricăpillus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">melagko/rufos, mela/nqric</foreign>, <sense id="n4289.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">black-haired</hi>, Gloss. Lat. Gr.</sense></entryFree>
atricolor: <entryFree id="n4290" type="hapax" key="a_tri^co^lor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ātrĭ-cŏlor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>ater</etym>, <sense id="n4290.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">blackcolored</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cadmi filiolis atricoloribus,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>letters written with ink</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Ep. 7, 52</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
atrides: <entryFree id="n4291" type="main" key="A_^tri_des"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^trīdes</orth>, v. Atreus, II. B.</entryFree>
atriensis: <entryFree id="n4292" type="main" key="a_tri^ensis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ātrĭensis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>atrium</etym>, <sense id="n4292.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the overseer of the hall</hi> or <hi rend="ital">court</hi> (atrium), and in gen. <hi rend="ital">of the house</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a steward</hi>, <hi rend="ital">major-domo</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:5:5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 5, 5, 4</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:1:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 2, 1, 16</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 2, 80</bibl>; <pb n="193" /> <cb n="ATRO" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:2:2:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 2, 2, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:5:2:38" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Par. 5, 2, 38</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 27 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl> (not elsewh. in Cic.; for in Parad. 5, 2, 36, atriensis et topiarii is a gloss; v. Orell. ad h. l.; so B. and K.); so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:2:5:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 2, 5, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:3:9" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 12, 3, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:3:19:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 3, 19, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 29, 9</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">53, 10</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">72, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:57" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 57</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
atriolum: <entryFree id="n4293" type="main" key="a_tri^o^lum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ātrĭŏlum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n4293.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small hall</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an antechamber</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> ad Q. Fr. 3, 1, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:10:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1, 10, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 4509</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,053:46:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Ezech. 46, 21</bibl> <hi rend="ital">bis;</hi> 46, 22; 46, 23.</sense></entryFree>
atriplex: <entryFree id="n4294" type="main" key="a_tri^plex"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ātrĭplex</orth>, <itype>plĭcis</itype> (more ancient form <orth extent="full" lang="la">ātrĭplexum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=29" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 29</bibl> Müll.), <gen>n.</gen> (<gen>m.</gen>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Plin. Val.</author> 4, 7</bibl>; <gen>f.</gen>, Aemil. Macer Cap. de Atripl.), = <foreign lang="greek">a)tra/facis</foreign>, <sense id="n4294.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the orach</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a kitchen vegetable</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:10:377" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 10, 377</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:3:42" default="NO">11, 3, 42</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 6, 31, § 99</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:117" default="NO" valid="yes">19, 7, 35, § 117</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:219" default="NO" valid="yes">20, 20, 83, § 219</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 5, 3, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
atritas: <entryFree id="n4295" type="main" key="a_tri^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ātrĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>ater</etym>, <sense id="n4295.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">blackness</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:5:5:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 5, 5, 11</bibl>; Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=28" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 28</bibl> Müll.; v. Müll. ad h. l.</sense></entryFree>
atritus: <entryFree id="n4296" type="spur" key="atri_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">atrītus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, a false read. for atritas in Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=28" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 28</bibl> Müll.</entryFree>
atrium: <entryFree id="n4297" type="main" key="a_tri^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ātrĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>acc. to Scaliger, from <foreign lang="greek">ai)/qrion</foreign>, subdiale, since it was a part of the uncovered portion of the house (but the atrium of the Romans was always covered); acc. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=161" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 161</bibl> Müll., from the Tuscan town Atria, where this style of architecture originated; cf. Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=13" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 13</bibl> Müll.; and Müller, Etrusk. 1, p. 254 sq.; but better from ater, acc. to the explanation of Servius: ibi etiam culina erat, unde et atrium dictum est; atrum enim erat ex fumo, ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:730" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 730</bibl></etym>. <sense id="n4297.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The fore-court</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hall</hi>, <hi rend="ital">entrance-room</hi>, <hi rend="ital">entry; that part of the Roman house into which one first came after passing the entrance</hi> (janua); cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:6:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 6, 4</bibl>; O. Müller, Archaeol. III. § 293, and Etrusk. above cited. In earlier times, the atrium was used as a dining-room, Cato ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 1, 726</bibl>. Here stood, opposite the door, the lectus genialis, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 87</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">here sat the housewife with her maidens spinning,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> adv. Gent. 2, 67</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">here clients were in attendance,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 5, 31</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:7:7" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 7, 7</bibl> and 91; <cit><quote lang="la">and here hung the family portraits and other paintings,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:34:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 34, 8, 19, § 55</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:2:90" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 2, 90</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:5:8:3" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 5, 8, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:26:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 26, 58</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:14:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Marc. 14, 54</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:18:15 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Joan. 18, 15 al.</bibl>—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg> in the <number>plur.</number>, of a single atrium: <cit><quote lang="la">Apparet domus intus et atria longa patescunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:483" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 483</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:260" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 260</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:20 al" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 8, 20 al.</bibl>—<usg type="style">Meton.</usg> for <hi rend="ital">the house itself</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec capient Phrygias atria nostra nurus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:16:184" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 16, 184</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:968" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 13, 968</bibl>.—So of <hi rend="ital">the entrance-room in the dwelling of the gods</hi>: dextrā laevāque deorum Atria nobilium (as it were clients, <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">supra</ref></xr>) valvis celebrantur apertis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:172" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 172</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:1:197" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 1, 197</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4297.1" n="II" level="1"> In temples and other public buildings there was often an atrium, <hi rend="ital">a hall</hi>, <hi rend="ital">court</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in atrio Libertatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:22:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 22, 59</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:15" default="NO" valid="yes">45, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:29" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Vestae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:7:19:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 7, 19, 2</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">also called atrium regium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 27</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:6:263" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 6, 263</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:3:1:30" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tr. 3, 1, 30</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">atrium tabernaculi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:27:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 27, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:6:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Lev. 6, 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in atriis Domūs Dei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:91:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Psa. 91, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">134, 2</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">Smith, Dict. Antiq.—So atrium auctionarium,</quote> <trans><tr>an auction-hall</tr>, <tr>auction-room</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 1, 3</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 3439</bibl>; and <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>, atria: <cit><quote lang="la">cum desertis Aganippes Vallibus esuriens migraret in atria Clio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:7:7" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 7, 7</bibl></cit>. Such halls were the Atria Licinia, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,001:6:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Quinct. 6, 25</bibl>: ATRIVM SVTORIVM, <hi rend="ital">the shoemakers' hall</hi>, a place in Rome, Calend. Praenest. <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> II. 386</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
atrius: <entryFree id="n4298" type="main" key="A_^tri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^trĭus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, Quintus Atrius, <sense id="n4298.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an officer in Cœsar's army</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
atrocitas: <entryFree id="n4299" type="main" key="a_^tro_ci^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā^trōcĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>atrox</etym>, <sense id="n4299.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the quality of</hi> atrox, <hi rend="ital">harshness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">horribleness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hideousness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hatefulness</hi> (having reference to the form, appearance, while <hi rend="ital">saevitas</hi> relates to the mind; hence the latter is used only of persons, the former of persons and things; v. Doed. Syn. I. p. 40; syn.: saevitas, duritia, acerbitas, crudelitas). </sense><sense id="n4299.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> (class., but only in prose): <cit><quote lang="la">si res ista gravissima suā sponte videretur, tamen ejus atrocitas necessitudinis nomine levaretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,001:16:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Quinct. 16, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipsius facti atrocitas aut indignitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:17:53" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 2, 17, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">facinoris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:12" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sceleris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 22:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 22, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">temporum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:48" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 48</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Calig. 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">poenae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:11" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Dom. 11</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n4299.2" n="II" level="1"> Of the mind or manners, <hi rend="ital">agitation</hi> (like that of the sea, v. ater and atrocitas maris, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:8:17:10" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 8, 17, 10</bibl>), <hi rend="ital">tumult rage</hi>, <hi rend="ital">savageness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">barbarity</hi>,<cb n="ATRO" />  <hi rend="ital">atrocity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cruelty</hi>, <hi rend="ital">roughness</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego quod in hac causā vehementior sum, non atrocitate animi moveor (quis enim est me mitior?) sed, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 4, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hae litterae invidiosam atrocitatem verborum habent, id. ad. Q. Fr. 1, 2, 2, § 6. So, morum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">consilium nefandae atrocitatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:48" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 48</bibl></cit>.—In phil. and jurid. lang. <hi rend="ital">severity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">harshness</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">atrocitas ista quo modo in veterem Academiam irruperit, nescio,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 44, 136</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">atrocitas formularum,</quote> <trans><tr>the rigid strictness of judicial formulas</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:1:37" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 7, 1, 37</bibl></cit> Spald.—In <number>plur.</number>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Met. 10</bibl>, c. 28, p. 252.</sense></entryFree>
atrociter: <entryFree id="n4300" type="main" key="a_^tro_ci^ter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā^trōcĭter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. atrox <sense id="n4300.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
atropatene: <entryFree id="n4301" type="main" key="A_^tro^pa^te_ne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^trŏpătēnē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)atropathnh/</foreign> (Strabo, 11, 506), <sense id="n4301.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the northern</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mountainous part of Media</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Aderbigian</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 13, 16, § 42</bibl> (Jan, <hi rend="ital">Atrapatene</hi>).—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^trŏpătēni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">its inhabitants</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 13, 16, § 42</bibl> (Jan, <hi rend="ital">Atrapateni</hi>).</sense></entryFree>
atrophia: <entryFree id="n4302" type="greek" key="a_^tro^phi_^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā^trŏphī^a</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)trofi/a</foreign>, <sense id="n4302.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a wasting consumption</hi>, <hi rend="ital">atrophy</hi> (in pure Lat., tabes), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 2:14" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 2, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:3:7" default="NO">3, 7</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Theod. Prisc.</author> 2, 11</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 4, 7, 27</bibl> (in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:3:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 3, 22</bibl>, written as Greek).</sense></entryFree>
atrophus: <entryFree id="n4303" type="greek" key="a_^tro^phus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā^trŏphus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/trofos</foreign> (not thriving), <sense id="n4303.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">in a state of atrophy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">consumptive</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:129" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 9, 33, § 129</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:122" default="NO" valid="yes">31, 10, 46, § 122</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">membra,</quote> <trans><tr>consumptive</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:152" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 22, 25, 73, § 152</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
atropos: <entryFree id="n4304" type="main" key="A_tro^po^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ātrŏpŏs</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/atropos</foreign> (not to be turned), <sense id="n4304.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one of the three Parcœ</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:10:44:6" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 10, 44, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:4:8:18" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 4, 8, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:3:68" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Th. 3, 68</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
atrotus: <entryFree id="n4305" type="greek" key="a_^tro_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā^trōtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/trwtos</foreign>, <sense id="n4305.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">invulnerable</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Fab. 28" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Fab. 28</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
atrox: <entryFree id="n4306" type="main" key="a_^trox"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ā^trox</orth>, <itype>ōcis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>from ater, as ferox from ferus, velox from velum. Atrocem hoc est asperum, crudelem, quod qui atro vultu sunt, asperitatem ac saevitiam prae se ferunt, Perott.; cf. Doed. Syn. I. p. 38 sq.</etym>, <sense id="n4306.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">dark</hi>, <hi rend="ital">gloomy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">frowning</hi>, <hi rend="ital">horrible</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hideous</hi>, <hi rend="ital">frightful</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dreadful;</hi> and trop., <hi rend="ital">savage</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cruel</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fierce</hi>, <hi rend="ital">atrocious</hi>, <hi rend="ital">harsh</hi>, <hi rend="ital">severe</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unyielding</hi> (of persons and things; while <hi rend="ital">saevus</hi> is used only of persons; v. Doed. as cited supra; very freq. and class.): exta, Naev. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 76, 6</bibl>: (fortunam) insanam esse aiunt, quia atrox, incerta, instabilisque sit, Pac. ap. Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 2, 23</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 125 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">sic Multi, animus quorum atroci vinctus malitiā est, Att., Trag. Rel. p. 141 Rib.: re atroci percitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:3:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 3, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">res tam scelesta, tam atrox, tam nefaria credi non potest,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:22:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 22, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">saevissimi domini atrocissima effigies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:52" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 52 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Agrippina semper atrox,</quote> <trans><tr>always gloomy</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 52</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 57</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">filia longo dolore atrox,</quote> <trans><tr>wild</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 16, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hiems,</quote> <trans><tr>severe</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:353" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 35, 80, § 353</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nox,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tempestas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 11, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">flagrantis hora Caniculae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:13:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 13, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">atrocissimae litterae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:25:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 25, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bellum magnum et atrox,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 5:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 5, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">facinus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non alia ante pugna atrocior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 1, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">periculum atrox,</quote> <trans><tr>dreadful</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:33:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 33, 5</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">negotium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 29:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 29, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">imperium (Manlii),</quote> <trans><tr>harsh</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">odium,</quote> <trans><tr>violent</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:275" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 275</bibl></cit> et saep.—Of discourse, <hi rend="ital">violent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bitter</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tunc admiscere huic generi orationis vehementi atque atroci genus illud alterum ... lenitatis et mansuetudinis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:49:200" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 49, 200</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Summa concitandi adfectūs accusatori in hoc est, ut id, quod objecit, aut quam atrocissimum aut etiam quam maxime miserabile esse videatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:1:15" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 1, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">peroratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 2, 2, § 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">et cuncta terrarum subacta Praeter atrocem animum Catonis,</quote> <trans><tr>stern</tr>, <tr>unyielding</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:1:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 1, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fides (Reguli),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:6:378" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 6, 378</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">virtus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:13:369" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 13, 369</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut verba atroci (i. e. rigido) stilo effoderent,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 4, 3</bibl></cit>.—Hence of that which is <hi rend="ital">fixed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">certain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">invincible</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">occisa est haec res, nisi reperio atrocem mi aliquam astutiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:4:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 3, 4, 7</bibl></cit> Lind. (perh. the figure is here drawn from the contest; the atrox pugna and atrox astutia are ludicrously contrasted with occidit res, <hi rend="ital">the cause had been lost</hi>, <hi rend="ital">if I had not come to the rescue with powerful art</hi>).—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">atrōcĭter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">violently</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fiercely</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cruelly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">harshly</hi> (only in prose): <cit><quote lang="la">atrociter minitari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fit aliquid,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 53 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:17:56" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 17, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agitare rem publicam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 37:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 37, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">invehi in aliquem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">deferre crimen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 13, 19 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multa facere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:59 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 59 al.</bibl></cit> —<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: atrocius in aliquem saevire, Liv. <cb n="ATTE" /> 42, 8; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 56</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">atrocius accipere labores itinerum,</quote> <trans><tr>reluctantly</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 23</bibl></cit>.— <hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">de ambitu atrocissime agere in senatu,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> ad Q. Fr. 2, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">leges atrocissime exercere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:58" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 58</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
atrusca: <entryFree id="n4307" type="hapax" key="atrusca"><orth extent="full" lang="la">atrusca</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n4307.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of grape</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 2, 16</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
atta: <entryFree id="n4308" type="gloss" key="atta1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">atta</orth>, like the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">a)/tta</foreign>, <sense id="n4308.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a salutation used to old men</hi>, <hi rend="ital">father;</hi> taken from the lang. of children (cf. Eust. ad Il. 1, 603), Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=11" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 11</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n4309" type="main" key="Atta2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Atta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4309.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a surname for persons who walk upon the tips of their shoes</hi>, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=11" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 11</bibl> Müll. (prob. from <foreign lang="greek">a)/|ttw</foreign> = <foreign lang="greek">a)/|ssw</foreign>, to spring, to hop). So the comic poet, C. Quintius Atta († 652 A.U.C.), of whose writings fragments yet remain; cf. Bähr, <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> Gesch. p. 71; Teuffel, Rom. <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> § 120; Both. Fragm. <usg type="style">Poet.</usg> Scen. II. p. 97 sq.; <cit><quote lang="la">Fest. l. l. Upon the signif. of the name Horace plays with the words: Recte necne crocum floresque perambulet Attae Fabula, si dubitem, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 79</bibl></cit>; cf. Weich. <usg type="style">Poet.</usg> Lat. p. 345 sq.—The ancestor of the Gens Claudia was an Atta, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:1" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
attactus: <entryFree id="n4310" type="main" key="attactus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attactus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of attingo.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n4311" type="main" key="attactus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attactus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>attingo</etym>, <sense id="n4311.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a touching</hi>, <hi rend="ital">touch</hi> (very rare, and only in <hi rend="ital">abl. sing.</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">Corium attactu non asperum ac durum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:5:8" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 5, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ille volvitur attactu nullo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:350" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 350</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 1, 35, 11</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
attacus: <entryFree id="n4312" type="greek" key="atta^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attăcus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ttako/s</foreign>, <sense id="n4312.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of locust</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:11:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Lev. 11, 22</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
attagen: <entryFree id="n4313" type="greek" key="atta^ge_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attăgēn</orth>, <itype>ēnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (cf. Schne<bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Gr. 2, p. 131</bibl>; Neue, Formenl. I. pp. 153, 318, 323 sq.) (<orth extent="full" lang="la">attăgēna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:2:37:3" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 2, 37, 3</bibl>, and 13, 61), = <foreign lang="greek">a)ttagh/n</foreign>, <sense id="n4313.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a meadow-bird</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the hazelhen</hi> or <hi rend="ital">heath-cock</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Tetrao bonasia, Linn.: Attagen maxume Ionius celeber,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:133" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 48, 68, § 133</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Non attagen Ionicus Jucundior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:2:54" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 2, 54</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
attagus: <entryFree id="n4314" type="foreign" key="atta^gus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attăgus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, among the Phrygians = hircus, <sense id="n4314.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a he-goat</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 5, p. 199</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
attalea: <entryFree id="n4315" type="main" key="Atta^le_a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Attălēa</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Attălīa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)attalei/a</foreign>, <sense id="n4315.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">name of a Greek city.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4315.1" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">In the region of Mysia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:121" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 30, 32, § 121</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4315.2" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">On the coast of Pamphylia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:14:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Act. 14, 25</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4315.3" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">In Galatia;</hi> v. Attalenses.</sense></entryFree>
attalenses: <entryFree id="n4316" type="main" key="Atta^lenses"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Attălenses</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4316.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of the town Attalea</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Attalia.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4316.1" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">In Pamphylia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 1, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 19</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4316.2" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">In the region of Mysia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:126" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 30, 33, § 126</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4316.3" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">In Galatia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:147" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 32, 42, § 147</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
attalis: <entryFree id="n4317" type="main" key="Atta^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Attălis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)attali/s</foreign>, <sense id="n4317.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the Attalian tribe in Athens</hi>, <hi rend="ital">so called in honor of King Attalus</hi> (v. Attalus), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 15</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
attalus: <entryFree id="n4318" type="main" key="Atta^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Attălus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/attalos</foreign>. <sense id="n4318.0" n="I. A." level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of several kings of Pergamos</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the most renowned of whom</hi>, <hi rend="ital">both from his wealth and his discovery of the art of weaving cloth from gold</hi>, <hi rend="ital">was Attalus III.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who made the Roman people his heir</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:196" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 48, 74, § 196</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:148" default="NO" valid="yes">33, 11, 53, § 148</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:2:20:2" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 2, 20, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:3:12:3" default="NO">3, 12, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:18:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 18, 5</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n4318.1" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Attălĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Attalus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Attalian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbes,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>Pergamean</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 11, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Attalicas supera vestes,</quote> <trans><tr>woven with gold</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:17:19" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 17, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Porticus aulaeis nobilis Attalicis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:30:12" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 30, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:659" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 14, 659</bibl>.—Also <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Attălĭca</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (sc. vestimenta), <hi rend="ital">garments of inwoven gold</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aurum intexere in eādem Asiā invenit Attalus rex, unde nomen Attalicis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:196" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 48, 74, § 196</bibl></cit>: torus, <hi rend="ital">ornamented with such cloth</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tapestry</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:5:6" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 5, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5:5:24" default="NO">5, 5, 24</bibl>.—<usg type="style">Meton.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">rich</hi>, <hi rend="ital">splendid</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brilliant</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Attalicis condicionibus Numquam dimoveas, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 1, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">divitiae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Jejun. 15 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n4318.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A general of Alexander the Great</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:13" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 13</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n4318.3" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A Macedonian</hi>, <hi rend="ital">enemy of Alexander</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:9" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 6, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
attamen: <entryFree id="n4319" type="main" key="atta^men"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attămen</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. tamen.</entryFree>
attamino: <entryFree id="n4320" type="main" key="atta_mi^no"><orth extent="full" lang="la">at-tāmĭno</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>), <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>ad-tamino, contr. instead of tagmino, from tago, tango; cf. contamino</etym>, <sense id="n4320.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to touch;</hi> and, in a bad sense, <hi rend="ital">to attack</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rob</hi> (only post-class. and rare), <bibl default="NO"><author>Capitol.</author> Gord. 27</bibl>.—Hence, also, <hi rend="ital">to dishonor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">contaminate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">defile</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">virginem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:21:3" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 21, 3</bibl></cit>: aliquem sacramentis Judaicis, Cod. Th. 3, 1, 5.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">facta et consulta alicujus imprudentia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Caes. 16" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Caes. 16</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
attat: <entryFree id="n4321" type="main" key="attat"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attat</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">attate</orth>, v. atat.</entryFree>
attegia: <entryFree id="n4322" type="main" key="atte^gi^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attĕgĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>acc. to some, an Arab. word; acc. to others, as if from attego, ĕre, to cover; so Van.</etym>, <sense id="n4322.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a tent</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Maurorum attegiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:14:196" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 14, 196</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 1396</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
attegrare: <entryFree id="n4323" type="gloss" key="attegra_re"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attegrāre</orth>, <sense id="n4323.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to pour out wine in sacrifices</hi>:<pb n="194" /> <cb n="ATTE" />  attegrare enim est minus facere, ut integrare in statum redigere, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=12" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 12</bibl> Müll. (Festus seems to have written the word ategrare, and to have considered the <hi rend="ital">a</hi> as privativum; the Cod. Berol. has also <hi rend="ital">ategrare</hi>, Fr.)</sense></entryFree>
atteius: <entryFree id="n4324" type="main" key="Atte_ius"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Attēius</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">Atēius</orth>), <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4324.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of several Latin grammarians.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4324.1" n="I" level="1"> Atteius Philologus, <hi rend="ital">a distinguished rhetorician and grammarian</hi>, <hi rend="ital">friend of Sallust and Asinius Pollio</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,004:7" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Gram. 7</bibl> and 10; <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 1, 601</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 273</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 45</bibl>; Fest. pp. 179, 182, 187, 248 al.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 102</bibl> P.; cf. Bähr, <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> Gesch. p. 523; Teuffel, Rom. <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> § 207, 1; <hi rend="ital">also an historian</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,004:10" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Gram. 10</bibl>; cf. Bähr, <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> Gesch. p. 285.—</sense><sense id="n4324.2" n="II" level="1"> Atteius Capito, <hi rend="ital">a contemporary of Augustus and Tiberius</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,004:10" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Gram. 10</bibl> and 22; Fest. pp. 176, 208, 227, 234 al.; cf. Bähr, <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> Gesch. p. 528; Teuffel, Rom. <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> § 260, 3; <hi rend="ital">he was also the founder of a distinguished law-school</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and adversary of Antistius Labeo</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 75</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:12:8" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 12, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:24:2" default="NO">2, 24, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:4:14:1 al" default="NO">4, 14, 1 al.</bibl>, cf. Bähr, <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> Gesch. p. 553; Hugo, Rechtsgeschichte, p. 868; Zimmern, Rechtsgeschichte, l. p. 305 sq.</sense></entryFree>
attelabus: <entryFree id="n4325" type="greek" key="atte^la^bus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attĕlăbus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)tte/labos</foreign>, <sense id="n4325.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a very small locust without wings</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">locustarum minumae sine pinnis, quos attelebos vocant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:29:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 29, 4, 29, § 92</bibl></cit>; cf. Schne<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:ad Aristot. H. A. 5:13:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ad Aristot. H. A. 5, 13, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
attemperate: <entryFree id="n4326" type="main" key="attempe^ra_te_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">at-tempĕrātē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. attempero <sense id="n4326.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
attemperies: <entryFree id="n4327" type="hapax" key="attempe^ri^es"><orth extent="full" lang="la">at-tempĕrĭes</orth>, <itype>ēi</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = temperies, Cod. Th. 9, 3, 2.</entryFree>
attempero: <entryFree id="n4328" type="main" key="attempe^ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">at-tempĕro</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>, Haase), <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n4328.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to fit</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adjust</hi>, <hi rend="ital">accommodate</hi> (only in the foll. exs.): <cit><quote lang="la">gladium sibi adtemperare, i. e. accommodare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 30:8" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 30, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">paenula, ut infundibulum inversum, est attemperata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:10:12:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 10, 12, 2</bibl></cit>.—Hence, * <orth extent="full" lang="la">attempĕrātē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">opportunely</hi>, <hi rend="ital">seasonably</hi>, = accommodate, commode: <cit><quote lang="la">Itane attemperate evenit, hodie in ipsis nuptiis Ut veniret, antehac numquam?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:5:4:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 5, 4, 13</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
attendo: <entryFree id="n4329" type="main" key="attendo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attendo</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>, Dietsch), <itype>tendi, tentum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, orig., <sense id="n4329.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to stretch</hi> something (e. g. the bow) <hi rend="ital">toward</hi> something; so only in Appul.: arcum, Met. 2, p. 122, 5.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n4329.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to direct</hi> or <hi rend="ital">turn toward</hi>, = advertere, admovere: aurem, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 238, 10</bibl>; Trag. Rel. p. 173 Rib. (cf. <itype>infra</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>): <cit><quote lang="la">attendere signa ad aliquid,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>to affix</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:2:29" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 2, 29</bibl></cit> (Halm, <hi rend="ital">aptare</hi>); so, manus caelo, <hi rend="ital">to stretch</hi> or <hi rend="ital">extend toward</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Met. 11, p. 263, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">caput eodem attentum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:Astr. 3:20" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> Astr. 3, 20</bibl></cit>.—Far more freq., </sense><sense id="n4329.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n4329.3" n="A" level="2"> Animum or animos attendere, or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> attendere, also animo attendere, <hi rend="ital">to direct the attention</hi>, <hi rend="ital">apply the mind to something</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to attend to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">consider</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">give heed to</hi> (cf.: advertere animum, and animadvertere; freq. and class.) </sense><sense id="n4329.4" n="1" level="3"> With <hi rend="ital">animum</hi> or <hi rend="ital">animos</hi>: animum ad quaerendum quid siet, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 238, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">dictis animum, Lucil. ib.: animum coepi attendere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:6:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 5, 6, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo tempore aures judex erigeret animumque attenderet?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si, cum animum attenderis, turpitudinem videas, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:8:35" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 8, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animum ad cavendum, Nep Alcib 5, 2: jubet peritos linguae attendere animum, pastorum sermo agresti an urbano propior esset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 4</bibl></cit>: praeterea et nostris animos attendere dictis atque adhibere velis, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 238, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">attendite animos ad ea, quae consequuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 15</bibl></cit>.—With a <hi rend="ital">rel.-clause</hi> as object: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc quid velim, animum attendite,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:prol. 24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. prol. 24</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4329.5" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">postquam attendi Magis et vi coepi cogere, ut etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:2:2:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 2, 2, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rem gestam vobis dum breviter expono, quaeso, diligenter attendite,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:chapter=9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">audi, audi atque attende,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:41:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Planc. 41, 98</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:13:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 13, 50</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:2:5:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 2, 5, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:66" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 6, 66</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:11:16 al" default="NO">11, 16 al.</bibl>—With <hi rend="ital">acc. of the thing</hi> or <hi rend="ital">person</hi> to which the attention is directed: <cit><quote lang="la">Glaucia solebat populum monere, ut, cum lex aliqua recitaretur, primum versum attenderet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,030:6:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rab. Post. 6, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed stuporem hominis attendite,</quote> <trans><tr>mark the stupidity</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:12:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 12, 30</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:35:161" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 35, 161</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 88:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 88, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:Ep 6:8:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep 6, 8, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:8:623 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 8, 623 al.</bibl>: me de invidiosis rebus dicentem attendite. <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sull 11, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quā re attendo te studiose,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:12:40" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 3, 12, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non attenderunt mandata,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> 2</bibl></cit> Esdr. 9, 34; ib. Job, 21, 5; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:28:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Isa. 28, 23</bibl>.— <hi rend="ital">Pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">versūs aeque prima et media et extrema pars attenditur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:50:192" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 50, 192</bibl></cit>. <cb n="ATTE" /> —With <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi> or <hi rend="ital">acc. and inf.</hi> as object: quid futurum est, si pol ego hanc discere artem attenderim? Pompon. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 238, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">non attendere superius illud eā re a se esse concessum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 34, 111</bibl></cit>.—With a <hi rend="ital">rel.clause</hi> or a <hi rend="ital">subjunct. with a particle</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum attendo, quā prudentiā sit Hortensius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,001:20:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Quinct. 20, 63</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hermagoras nec, quid dicat, attendere nec ... videatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:6:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 1, 6, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">forte lubuit adtendere, quae res maxume tanta negotia sustinuisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 53:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 53, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Oro, parumper Attendas, quantum de legibus queratur etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:10:251" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 10, 251</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">attende, cur, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:2, prol. 14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 2, prol. 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">attendite ut sciatis prudentiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,029:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Prov. 4, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Attendite, ne justitiam vestram faciatis etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 6, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,034:1:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Eccli. 1, 38</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">13, 10</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">28, 30</bibl>.— With <hi rend="ital">de</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum de necessitate attendemus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,038:24:84" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Part.
