Or. 24, 84</bibl></cit>.—With <case>dat.</case> (post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">sermonibus malignis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:7:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 7, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cui magis quam Caesari attendant?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:65:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Pan. 65, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:591" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 591</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">attendit mandatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,034:32:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Eccli. 32, 28</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,029:7:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Prov. 7, 24</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">attendite vobis,</quote> <trans><tr>take heed to yourselves</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:17:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Luc. 17, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:5:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 5, 35</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,015:4:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 1 Tim. 4, 16</bibl>.—So in Suet. several times in the signif. <hi rend="ital">to devote attention to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to study</hi>, = studere: <cit><quote lang="la">eloquentiae plurimum attendit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:53" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">juri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Galb. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">extispicio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:56" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ner. 56</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">abl. with ab</hi> (after the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">prose/xein a)po/ tinos</foreign>; <cit><quote lang="la">eccl. Lat.): attende tibi a pestifero,</quote> <trans><tr>beware of</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,034:11:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Eccli. 11, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">attendite ab omni iniquo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 17, 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:7:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 7, 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:12:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Luc. 12, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">20, 46</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4329.6" n="3" level="3"> With <hi rend="ital">animo</hi> (ante- and post-class. and rare): <cit><quote lang="la">cum animo attendi ad quaerendum, Pac., Trag. Rel. p. 79 Rib.: nunc quid petam, aequo animo attendite,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:prol. 20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. prol. 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid istud sit, animo attendatis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Flor. 9</bibl></cit>: ut magis magisque attendant animo, Vulg. Eccli. prol.; so, <cit><quote lang="la">in verbis meis attende in corde tuo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 16, 25</bibl></cit>.—* </sense><sense id="n4329.7" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To strive eagerly for</hi> something, <hi rend="ital">long for</hi>: puer, ne attenderis Petere a me id quod nefas sit concedi tibi, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 238, 19</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 173 Rib.).—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">attentus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> </sense><sense id="n4329.8" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Directed to</hi> something, <hi rend="ital">attentive</hi>, <hi rend="ital">intent on</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ut animus in spe attentus fuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:2:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 2, 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quo magis attentas aurīs animumque reposco,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:920" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 920</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Verba per attentam non ibunt Caesaris aurem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:1:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 1, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si attentos animos ad decoris conservationem tenebimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:37:131" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 37, 131</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum respiceremus attenti ad gentem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Thren. 4, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eaque dum animis attentis admirantes excipiunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:58:197" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 58, 197</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acerrima atque attentissima cogitatio,</quote> <trans><tr>a very acute and close manner of thinking</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:5:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 5, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">et attentum monent Graeci a principio faciamus judicem et docilem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 79, 323</bibl></cit>; 2, 19, 80; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:16:23" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 1, 16, 23</bibl>; Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 1, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ut patris attenti, lenonis ut insidiosi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 172</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">judex circa jus attentior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:5:21" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 4, 5, 21</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4329.9" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Intent on</hi>, <hi rend="ital">striving after</hi> something, <hi rend="ital">careful</hi>, <hi rend="ital">frugal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">industrious</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">unum hoc vitium fert senectus hominibus: Attentiores sumus ad rem omnes quam sat est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:5:3:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 5, 3, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nimium ad rem in senectā attente sumus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 8, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tum enim cum rem habebas, quaesticulus te faciebat attentiorem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:16:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 16, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">paterfamilias et prudens et attentus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,001:chapter=3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Quinct. 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Durus, ait, Voltei, nimis attentusque videris Esse mihi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 7, 91</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">asper et attentus quaesitis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:6:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 2, 6, 82</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:15:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 15, 44</bibl></cit> Matth.: <cit><quote lang="la">qui in re adventiciā et hereditariā tam diligens, tam attentus esset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">antiqui attenti continentiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:2:5:5" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 2, 5, 5</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: hortor vos attentiori studio lectionem facere, * Vulg. Eccli. prol.—Hence, <pos>adv.</pos>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">atten-tē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">attentively</hi>, <hi rend="ital">carefully</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">attente officia servorum fungi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:1:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 1, 14</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">audire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 3 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:35:148" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 35, 148</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:54:200" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 54, 200</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">legere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 7, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">parum attente dicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:4:15" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 4, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">custodire attente,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,006:22:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Jos. 22, 5</bibl></cit>.— <hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">attentius audire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acrius et attentius cogitare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:2:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 5, 2, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">attentius agere aliquid,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 52:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 52, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">spectare,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 197</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">invicem diligere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> 1</bibl></cit> Pet 1, 22.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">attentissime audire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:61:259" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 61, 259</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
attentatio: <entryFree id="n4330" type="hapax" key="attenta_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attentātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>attento</etym>, <sense id="n4330.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a trying</hi>, <hi rend="ital">attempting</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Ep. 6:9" default="NO"><author>Symm.</author> Ep. 6, 9</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
attente: <entryFree id="n4331" type="main" key="attente_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attentē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. attendo, <sense id="n4331.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">P. a. fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
attentio: <entryFree id="n4332" type="main" key="attenti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attentĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>attendo</etym>, <sense id="n4332.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">attentiveness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">attention</hi>, <hi rend="ital">application.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4332.1" n="A" level="2"> With <hi rend="ital">animi</hi>: reliqua sunt in curā, attentione animi,<cb n="ATTE" />  cogitatione, vigilantiā, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:35:150" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 35, 150</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4332.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">docilem sine dubio et haec ipsa praestat attentio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:1:34" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 4, 1, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum (servos) tantā cruciāsti attentione,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,033:12:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Sap. 12, 20</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
attento: <entryFree id="n4333" type="main" key="attento"><orth extent="full" lang="la">at-tento</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">adtempto</orth>, K. and H.; <orth extent="full" lang="la">at-tempto</orth>, <itype>Kayser</itype>, Rib., Halm, Queck), <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, lit., <sense id="n4333.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to strive after</hi> something, <hi rend="ital">to attempt</hi>, <hi rend="ital">essay</hi>, <hi rend="ital">try</hi>, <hi rend="ital">make trial of; to solicit; to assail</hi>, <hi rend="ital">attack</hi> (class. in prose and poetry): <cit><quote lang="la">digitis mollibus arcum attemptat,</quote> <trans><tr>attempts to draw</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> Rapt. Pros. 3, 217</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem lacrimis,</quote> <trans><tr>to attempt to move</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:4:11" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 4, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praeteriri omnino fuerit satius quam attemptatum deseri,</quote> <trans><tr>begun</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:28:110" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 28, 110</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">attemptata defectio,</quote> <trans><tr>the attempted revolt</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:15:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 23, 15, 7</bibl></cit> (Weissenb., <hi rend="ital">temptata</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">omnium inimicos diligenter cognoscere, colloqui, attemptare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Capuam propter plurimas belli opportunitates ab illā impiā et sceleratā manu attemptari suspicabamur,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>moved by persuasion to revolt</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:chapter=4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne compositae orationis insidiis sua fides attemptetur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:61:208" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 61, 208</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mecum facientia jura Si tamen adtemptas,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>attempt to shake</tr>, <tr>attack</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec hoc testamentum ejus quisquam attemptavit,</quote> <trans><tr>sought to annul</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:7:8:3" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 7, 8, 3</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">sententiam judicis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:12:6:23" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 12, 6, 23</bibl></cit>: pudicitiam, <hi rend="ital">to seek to defile</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pollute</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:47:10:10" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 47, 10, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">annonam,</quote> <trans><tr>to make dearer</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:47:11:6" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 47, 11, 6</bibl></cit>.—Of a hostile attack: <cit><quote lang="la">vi attemptantem repellere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 13, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam curabo sentiat, Quos attentārit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:5:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 5, 2, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haud illum bello attemptare juvencis Sunt animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:4:71" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 4, 71</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: Quae aegritudo insolens mentem attemptat tuam? Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 322, 18</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 84 Rib.).</sense></entryFree>
attentus: <entryFree id="n4334" type="main" key="attentus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attentus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. <itype>attendo</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n4335" type="main" key="attentus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attentus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of attineo.</entryFree>
attenuate: <entryFree id="n4336" type="main" key="atte^nu^a_te_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attĕnŭātē</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>), <pos>adv.</pos>, v. attenuo, <sense id="n4336.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">P. a. fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
attenuatio: <entryFree id="n4337" type="main" key="atte^nu^a_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attĕnŭātĭo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>attenuo</etym>, <sense id="n4337.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a diminishing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lessening</hi> (only in the two foll. exs.): attenuatio suspitionis, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 2, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">verborum attenuatio,</quote> <trans><tr>simplicity</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 11</bibl></cit>; cf. attenuatus.</sense></entryFree>
attenuatus: <entryFree id="n4338" type="main" key="atte^nu^a_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attĕnŭātus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, from attenuo.</entryFree>
attenuo: <entryFree id="n4339" type="main" key="atte^nu^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">at-tĕnŭo</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>, Lachm., Merk., Weissenb.; <orth extent="full" lang="la">att-</orth>, <itype>Kayser</itype>, K. and H., L. Müller), <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n4339.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to make thin</hi> or <hi rend="ital">weak; to thin</hi>, <hi rend="ital">attenuate; to weaken</hi>, <hi rend="ital">enfeeble; to lessen</hi>, <hi rend="ital">diminish.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4339.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: aëna Signa manus dextras ostendunt adtenuari Saepe salutantūm tactu, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:317" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 317</bibl> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">attritum mentum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 43</bibl></cit>): <cit><quote lang="la">bellum (servile) exspectatione Pompeii attenuatum atque imminutum est, adventu sublatum ac sepultum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:11:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 11, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">legio proeliis attenuata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 89</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">diutino morbo viribus admodum adtenuatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 49</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:11" default="NO" valid="yes">25, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">fame attenuari,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Job, 18, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,049:14:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Jer. 14, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">macie attenuari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,012:13:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 2 Reg. 13, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sortes adtenuatae,</quote> <trans><tr>diminished</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">foliorum exilitate usque in fila attenuatā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 6, 16, § 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(lingua) attenuans lambendo cutem homines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:172 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 11, 37, 65, § 172 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Non falx attenuat frondatorum arboris umbram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adtenuant juvenum vigilatae corpora noctes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:1:735" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 1, 735</bibl></cit> (cf. <itype>infra</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>): <cit><quote lang="la">patrias opes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:844" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 8, 844</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:4:5:38" default="NO"><author>id.</author> P. 4, 5, 38</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4339.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">curas lyrā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:4:1:16" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 4, 1, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4, 6, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">luctus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0800,001:ad Liv. 342" default="NO"><author>Albin.</author> ad Liv. 342</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">insignem attenuat deus,</quote> <trans><tr>brings low</tr>, <tr>abases</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:34:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 34, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">attenuabit omnes deos terrae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,044:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Soph. 2, 11</bibl></cit>: hujusmodi partes sunt virtutis amplificandae, si suadebimus; attenuandae, si ab his dehortabimur, Auct. ad. <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 3, 3, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">attenuabitur gloria Jacob,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:17:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Isa. 17, 4</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">attĕnŭātus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">enfeebled</hi>, <hi rend="ital">weakened</hi>, <hi rend="ital">reduced</hi>, <hi rend="ital">weak.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4339.3" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">adtenuatus amore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:489" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 489</bibl></cit>: continuatione laborum, August. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:21" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 21</bibl>: fortuna rei familiaris attenuatissima, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 4, 41</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">voce paululum attenuatā,</quote> <trans><tr>with a voice a little suppressed</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acuta atque attenuata nimis acclamatio,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 12, 21</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi> not in use. —<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: fortunae familiares attenuatissimae, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 4, 41, 53</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4339.4" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n4339.5" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Feeble</hi>, <hi rend="ital">destitute</hi>, <hi rend="ital">poor</hi> (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">Siattenuatus frater tuus vendiderit etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:25:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Lev. 25, 25</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">25, 35</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">25, 47</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2</bibl> Esdr. 5, 18. —</sense><sense id="n4339.6" n="B" level="2"> Esp., of discourse. </sense><sense id="n4339.7" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Shortened</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brief</hi>: ipsa illa [pro Roscio] juvenilis redundantia<pb n="195" /> <cb n="ATTE" />  multa habet attenuata, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:30:108" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 30, 108</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4339.8" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Too much refined</hi>, <hi rend="ital">affected</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">itaque ejus oratio nimiā religione attenuata doctis et attente audientibus erat illustris,</quote> <trans><tr>hence his discourse was so delicately formed</tr>, <tr>through excessive scrupulousness</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=82" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 82</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4339.9" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Meagre</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dry</hi>, <hi rend="ital">without ornament</hi>: attenuata (oratio) est, quae demissa est usque ad usitatissimam puri sermonis consuetudinem, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 4, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">attenuata verborum constructio,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 10, 15</bibl></cit>.—* <hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">at-tenuātē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">simply</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">attenuate presseque dicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:55:201" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 55, 201</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
attermino: <entryFree id="n4340" type="hapax" key="attermi^no"><orth extent="full" lang="la">at-termĭno</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n4340.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to set bounds to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to measure</hi>, <hi rend="ital">limit</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Deos filo humano,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 3, p. 107</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
attero: <entryFree id="n4341" type="main" key="atte^ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">at-tĕro</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>, Dietsch), <itype>trīvi, trītum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (<sense id="n4341.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">perf. inf.</hi> atteruisse, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:4:48" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 4, 48</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:Long. p. 2234" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> Long. p. 2234</bibl> P.), <hi rend="ital">to rub one thing against another;</hi> hence, in gen., <hi rend="ital">to rub away</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wear out</hi> or <hi rend="ital">diminish by rubbing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to waste</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wear away</hi>, <hi rend="ital">weaken</hi>, <hi rend="ital">impair</hi>, <hi rend="ital">exhaust.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4341.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> (most freq. after the Aug. per.; in Cic. only once as <hi rend="ital">P. a.;</hi> <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">infra</ref></xr>): insons Cerberus leniter atterens caudam, <hi rend="ital">rubbing against</hi> or <hi rend="ital">upon</hi> (sc. Herculi), * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:19:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 19, 30</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">asinus spinetis se scabendi causā atterens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:204" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 74, 95, § 204</bibl></cit>: aures, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:4:9:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 4, 9, 11</bibl> (cf. antestor): <cit><quote lang="la">bucula surgentes atterat herbas,</quote> <trans><tr>tramples upon</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">opere insuetas atteruisse manus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:4:48" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 4, 48</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5:3:24" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 5, 3, 24</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:158" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 63, 63, § 158</bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">dentes usu atteruntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 7, 16, 15, § 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">attrivit sedentis pedem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,004:22:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Num. 22, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vestem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:23:3:10" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 23, 3, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:2:16" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 11, 2, 16</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">Cels. praef.: vestimenta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:29:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Deut. 29, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:51:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Isa. 51, 6</bibl>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, of sand worn by the water flowing over it: <cit><quote lang="la">attritas versabat rivus harenas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:456" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 456</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4341.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to destroy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">waste</hi>, <hi rend="ital">weaken</hi>, <hi rend="ital">impair</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">postquam utrimque legiones item classes saepe fusae fugataeque et alteri alteros aliquantum adtriverant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 79:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 79, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magna pars (exercitūs) temeritate ducum adtrita est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 85:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 85, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Italiae opes bello,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 5:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 4</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 10</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 89</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 56</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:6" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 6 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:2:392" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 2, 392</bibl> Drak.: <cit><quote lang="la">nec publicanus atterit (Germanos),</quote> <trans><tr>exhausts</tr>, <tr>drains</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">famam atque pudorem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 16:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 16, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">et vincere inglorium et atteri sordidum arbitrabatur,</quote> <trans><tr>and to suffer injury in his dignity</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 9</bibl></cit> Rupert.: <cit><quote lang="la">eo tempore, quo praecipue alenda ingenia atque indulgentiā quādam enutrienda sunt, asperiorum tractatu rerum atteruntur,</quote> <trans><tr>are enfeebled</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8</bibl></cit>, prooem. 4: <cit><quote lang="la">filii ejus atterentur egestate,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Job, 20, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nec res atteritur longo sufflamine litis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:16:50" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 16, 50</bibl></cit>.— Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">attrītus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">rubbed off</hi>, <hi rend="ital">worn off</hi> or <hi rend="ital">away</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wasted.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4341.3" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n4341.4" n="1" level="3"> In gen.: ut rictum ejus (simulacri) ac mentum paulo sit attritius, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 43</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ansa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:6:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 6, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vomer,</quote> <trans><tr>worn bright</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 1, 46</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:16" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 8, 16</bibl> Rupert.: <cit><quote lang="la">caelaturae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:157" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 12, 55, § 157</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 109, 9</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4341.5" n="2" level="3"> In medicine, attritae partes or <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi> <itype>attrita, ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (sc. membra), <hi rend="ital">bruised</hi>, <hi rend="ital">excoriated parts of the body</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">medetur et attritis partibus sive oleo etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 24, 7, 28, § 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">attritis medetur cinis muris silvatici etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:30:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 30, 8, 22, § 70</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4341.6" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: attrita frons, <hi rend="ital">a shameless</hi>, <hi rend="ital">impudent face</hi> (lit. <hi rend="ital">a smooth face</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to which shame no longer clings;</hi> cf. perfrico), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:13:242" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 13, 242</bibl> Rupert.; so, <cit><quote lang="la">domus Israël attritā fronte,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,053:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Ezech. 3, 7</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi> and <pos>adv.</pos> not used.</sense></entryFree>
atterraneus: <entryFree id="n4342" type="hapax" key="atterra_ne^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">at-terrānĕus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>terraneus</etym>, <sense id="n4342.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">belonging to the earth</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fulmina,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>coming from the earth</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 2:49" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 2, 49</bibl></cit> dub.</sense></entryFree>
attertiarius: <entryFree id="n4343" type="hapax" key="atterti^a_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">at-tertĭārĭus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">e)pi/tritos</foreign>, <sense id="n4343.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the whole and a third</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 3, 1</bibl>; cf. as.</sense></entryFree>
attertiatus: <entryFree id="n4344" type="hapax" key="atterti^a_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">at-tertĭātus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, as if <mood>Part.</mood> of attertio, āre [adtertius], <sense id="n4344.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">boiled down to a third part</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lixivium attertiatum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Plin. Val.</author> 1, 29</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
attestatio: <entryFree id="n4345" type="main" key="attesta_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attestātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>attestor</etym>, <sense id="n4345.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an attesting</hi>, <hi rend="ital">attestation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">testimony</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> Somn. Scip. 2, 9</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Treb. Pol.</author> XXX. Tyr. 30</bibl>: juris jurandi, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:43:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 43, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
attestor: <entryFree id="n4346" type="main" key="attestor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">at-testor</orth>, <itype>ātus, 1</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos>, <sense id="n4346.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to bear witness to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to attest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">prove</hi>, <hi rend="ital">confirm</hi>, <hi rend="ital">corroborate</hi> (very rare, and not before the Aug. per.; for in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:chapter=29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sull. 29 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl> the reading should be, with Cod. Erf. and Lambin., ad testandam omnium memoriam; v. Frotsch. ad h. l.; <cit><quote lang="la">so B. and K.): hoc attestatur brevis Aesopi fabula,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:1:10:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 1, 10, 3</bibl></cit>: Plin. <cb n="ATTI" /> H. N. praef. § <cit><quote lang="la">10: M. Cato id saepenumero attestatus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:4:12" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 4, 12</bibl></cit>: attestata fulgura, in the lang. of omens, <hi rend="ital">lightnings which confirm that which was indicated by previous lightnings</hi>, <hi rend="ital">confirmatory</hi> (opp. peremptalibus, which cancel, annul, what was previously indicated): <cit><quote lang="la">attestata (fulmina), quae prioribus consentiunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 2:49" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 2, 49</bibl></cit>: attestata dicebantur fulgura, quae iterato fiebant, videlicet significationem priorum attestantia, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=12" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 12</bibl> Müll.; cf. Müll. Etrusk. 2, p. 170.</sense></entryFree>
attexo: <entryFree id="n4347" type="main" key="attexo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">at-texo</orth>, <itype>texui, textum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <sense id="n4347.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To weave on</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to</hi> something (rare, and only in prose): <cit><quote lang="la">turres contabulantur, pinnae loricaeque ex cratibus attexuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">attexti capite crines,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 11, p. 260, 35</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4347.1" n="II" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to add</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">secundum actum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:5:2" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 5, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vos autem ad id, quod erit immortale, partem attexitote mortalem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=11" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tim. 11 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
atthis: <entryFree id="n4348" type="main" key="Atthis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Atthis</orth> (better than <orth extent="full" lang="la">Attis</orth>), <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <sense id="n4348.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adj. f.</hi>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)atqi/s</foreign>. </sense><sense id="n4348.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Attic</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Athenian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">matres,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:11:53" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 11, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lingua,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 1</bibl></cit>, praef. Oud. —Hence, </sense><sense id="n4348.2" n="II" level="1"> <pos>Subst.</pos> </sense><sense id="n4348.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">An Athenian woman</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Hippol. 107" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Hippol. 107</bibl>.—Esp., <hi rend="ital">Philomela;</hi> and, since she was changed to a nightingale, meton. for <hi rend="ital">a nightingale</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:1:54:9" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 1, 54, 9</bibl>. Also <hi rend="ital">Procne</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the sister of Philomela;</hi> acc. to the fable (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Herc. Oet. 200" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Herc. Oet. 200</bibl>), changed into a swallow; hence, meton. for <hi rend="ital">a swallow</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:5:67" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 5, 67</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4348.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A female friend of Sappho</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Non oculis grata est Atthis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:15:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 15, 18</bibl></cit> Merk. ubi v. Loers.—</sense><sense id="n4348.5" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A name for Attica</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Atthide temptantur gressus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1116" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 1116</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Carm. 5, 44</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:3:4" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 3, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:7:10" default="NO">2, 7, 10</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
attianus: <entryFree id="n4349" type="main" key="Attia_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Attiānus</orth>, v. Attius.</entryFree>
attica: <entryFree id="n4350" type="main" key="Atti^ca"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Attĭca</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Attĭcē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)attikh/</foreign>. <sense id="n4350.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The most distinguished province of Greece</hi>, <hi rend="ital">situated in Hellas proper</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with Athens as capital.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4350.1" n="A" level="2"> Form <orth extent="full" lang="la">Attĭca</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:3:7" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 3, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:2:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 1, 2, 30</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4350.2" n="B" level="2"> Form <orth extent="full" lang="la">Attĭcē</orth>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:1:section=1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 1, § 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:23" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 7, 11, § 23</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4350.3" n="II" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Attĭca</orth>, <hi rend="ital">the name of the daughter of T. Pompomus Atticus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 12, 1</bibl>; cf. Atticula.</sense></entryFree>
attice: <entryFree id="n4351" type="main" key="Atti^ce_1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Attĭcē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. Atticus, II. A. <sense id="n4351.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n4352" type="main" key="Atti^ce_2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Attĭcē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)attikh/</foreign>, <sense id="n4352.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Attic</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ochra, quae Attice nominatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:5:18:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 5, 18, 19</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:179" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 10, 66, § 179</bibl>, Ochra Attica).</sense></entryFree>
<entryFree id="n4353" type="main" key="Atti^ce_3" n="3"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Attĭcē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, v. Attica.</entryFree>
atticisso: <entryFree id="n4354" type="greek" key="atti^cisso"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attĭcisso</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ttiki/zw</foreign>, <sense id="n4354.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to imitate the Athenian manner of speaking</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc argumentum graecissat, tamen non atticissat, verum sicilicissitat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:prol. 12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. prol. 12</bibl></cit>; App. Flor. n. 18, p. 362, 12.</sense></entryFree>
atticula: <entryFree id="n4355" type="main" key="Atti^cu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Attĭcŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n4355.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">daughter of Atticus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 5</bibl>; v. Attica, II.</sense></entryFree>
atticurges: <entryFree id="n4356" type="greek" key="Atti^curges"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Attĭcurges</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)attikourgh/s</foreign>, <sense id="n4356.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">made in the Attic manner</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">columna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 3, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
atticus: <entryFree id="n4357" type="main" key="Atti^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Attĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)attiko/s</foreign>. <sense id="n4357.0" n="I" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Attica</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Athens</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Attic</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Athenian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Athenae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 5, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:4:36 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 3, 4, 36 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">civis Attica atque libera,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:159" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 159</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">civis Attica,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:3:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 3, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">disciplina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:3:5:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 3, 5, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 3, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">regio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 12, 15, § 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">thymum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 10, 31, § 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mel,</quote> <trans><tr>of Mount Hymettus</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:ib" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">apis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:4:30" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 5, 4, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sal,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 31, 7, 41, § 87</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">columnae,</quote> <trans><tr>formed in the Attic manner</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:179" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 36, 23, 56, § 179</bibl></cit> (cf. atticurges): <cit><quote lang="la">ochra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:179" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 37, 10, 66, § 179</bibl></cit> (cf. 2. Attice): <cit><quote lang="la">paelex,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>Philomela</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:10:51" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 10, 51</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:537" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 537</bibl>: fides, i. e. <hi rend="ital">sincere</hi>, <hi rend="ital">firm</hi>, prov., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:23:4" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 23, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">profluvius, a disease of animals,</quote> <trans><tr>the glanders</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> Art. Vet. 1, 17</bibl></cit> and 38.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Attĭci</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the Athenians</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:1:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 1, 2, 6</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4357.1" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n4357.2" n="A" level="2"> Appel., to designate the highest grade of style, philosophy, eloquence, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,041:3:7" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Opt. Gen. 3, 7</bibl> sqq.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:82:284" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 82, 284</bibl> sqq.: <cit><quote lang="la">Demosthenes, quo ne Athenas quidem ipsas magis credo fuisse Atticas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:7:23" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 7, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lepos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:3:20" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 3, 20</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: Attici, <hi rend="ital">orators of the Attic stamp</hi> (opp. Asiani): et antiqua quidem illa divisio inter Atticos atque Asianos fuit: cum hi pressi et integri, contra inflati illi et inanes haberentur; <cit><quote lang="la">in his nihil superflueret, illis judicium maxime ac modus deesset, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:10:16 sq" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 10, 16 sq.</bibl></cit>—And transf. to other things, <hi rend="ital">excellent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">preeminent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">preferable</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">logi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:3:1:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 3, 1, 66</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Attĭcē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">in the Attic</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Athenian manner</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=84" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 84</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">290</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,041:3:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Opt. Gen. 3, 8</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:10:18" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 10, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">loqui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:1:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 8, 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pressi oratores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:10:18" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 12, 10, 18</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4357.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A surname of T. Pomponius</hi>, <cb n="ATTI" /> <hi rend="ital">the intimate friend of Cicero</hi>, <hi rend="ital">given to him on account of his long residence at Athens.</hi> His biography is found in Nepos.—</sense><sense id="n4357.4" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A friend of Ovid</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:1:9:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 1, 9, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:2:4:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> P. 2, 4, 2</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n4357.5" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Antonius Atticus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a Latin rhetorician</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Suas. 2, p. 19" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Suas. 2, p. 19</bibl> Bip.—</sense><sense id="n4357.6" n="E" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Vipsanius Atticus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Contr. 2:13, p. 184" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Contr. 2, 13, p. 184</bibl> Bip.</sense></entryFree>
attigo: <entryFree id="n4358" type="main" key="atti^go"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attĭgo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>), v. attingo <sense id="n4358.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>
attiguus: <entryFree id="n4359" type="main" key="atti^gu^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attĭgŭus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>attingo, as ambiguus, assiduus, continuus, from ambigo, assideo, contineo</etym>, <sense id="n4359.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">touching</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bordering on</hi>, <hi rend="ital">contiguous to</hi> (only post-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">domus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 4, p. 148, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nemus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6</bibl></cit>, p. 178, 18; <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul. Nol.</author> Nat. XIII. S. Fel. 333</bibl> Murat.</sense></entryFree>
attillo: <entryFree id="n4360" type="hapax" key="attillo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">at-tillo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>), <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>qs. from til lo, hence titillo</etym>, <sense id="n4360.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to tickle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">please</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1672,001:Rer. Gest. Alex. M. 3:41" default="NO"><author>Jul. Val.</author> Rer. Gest. Alex. M. 3, 41</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
attilus: <entryFree id="n4361" type="main" key="atti^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">attĭlus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n4361.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of large fish found in the Po</hi>: Acipenser huso, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 15, 17, § 44</bibl> (called by the Italians <hi rend="ital">Ladano</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Adello</hi>).</sense></entryFree>
attin: <entryFree id="n4362" type="main" key="Attin"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Attin</orth>, v. Attis.</entryFree>
attinae: <entryFree id="n4363" type="main" key="atti^nae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">at-tĭnae</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>), <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>attineo</etym>, <sense id="n4363.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">stones built up like a wall for a boundary mark</hi>, Sic. Fl. pp. 4 and 6 Goes.</sense></entryFree>
attineo: <entryFree id="n4364" type="main" key="atti^ne^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">at-tĭnĕo</orth> (<orth extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>, <itype>Dietsch</itype>, Weissenb.), <itype>tĭnui, tentum, 2</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> and <gen>n.</gen> <etym>teneo</etym>. <sense id="n4364.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Act.</hi>, (so only ante-class. or in the histt.; most freq. in Plaut. and Tac.). </sense><sense id="n4364.1" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To hold to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to bring</hi> or <hi rend="ital">hold near</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem ante oculos attinere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:1:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 5, 1, 30</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4364.2" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To hold</hi> or <hi rend="ital">detain at some point</hi> (class. retinere), <hi rend="ital">to hold fast</hi>, <hi rend="ital">keep hold of</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to hold</hi>, <hi rend="ital">keep</hi>, <hi rend="ital">detain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hold back</hi>, <hi rend="ital">delay</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">testes vinctos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:3:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 4, 3, 63</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 2, 2, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">animum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:8:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 4, 8, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lectos viros castris attinere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 52</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">6, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">prensam dextram vi attinere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 35</bibl></cit>; 2, 10; 3, 71 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cunctos, qui carcere attinebantur, necari jussit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 19</bibl></cit>; 3, 36 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; 12, 68; 13, 15; 13, 27; <cit><quote lang="la">15, 57: set ego conperior Bocchum Punicā fide simul Romanum et Numidam spe pacis adtinuisse,</quote> <trans><tr>detained</tr>, <tr>amused</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 108:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 108, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad ea Corbulo satis comperto Vologesen defectione Hyrcaniae attineri,</quote> <trans><tr>is detained</tr>, <tr>hindered</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 13, 37 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">13, 50</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">14, 33</bibl>; 14, 56 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; 16, 19; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 2, 14 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>—</sense><sense id="n4364.3" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To hold possession of</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to occupy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">keep</hi>, <hi rend="ital">guard</hi>, <hi rend="ital">preserve</hi>: Quamque at tinendi magni dominatūs sient, Ter. Fragm. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:47:157" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 47, 157</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ripam Danubii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4364.4" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Neutr.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4364.5" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To stretch out to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to reach to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc jam cultros attinet, i. e. ad cultros,</quote> <trans><tr>now he is reaching forth for</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:2:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 2, 2, 17</bibl></cit>.—Hence, of relations of place, <hi rend="ital">to extend</hi> or <hi rend="ital">stretch somewhere</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Scythae ad Borysthenem atque inde ad Tanain attinent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:2:9" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 6, 2, 9</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4364.6" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To belong somewhere;</hi> only in the third person: hoc (res) attinet (more rare, haec attinent) ad me (less freq. simply me), or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> hoc attinet, <hi rend="ital">this belongs to me</hi>, <hi rend="ital">concerns me</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pertains</hi> or <hi rend="ital">appertains to me</hi>, <hi rend="ital">relates</hi> or <hi rend="ital">refers to me;</hi> cf. Rudd. II. p. 209; Roby, § 1534 (the most usu. class. signif. of the word). </sense><sense id="n4364.7" n="1" level="3"> Attinet (attinent) ad aliquem: <cit><quote lang="la">negotium hoc ad me attinet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:2:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 2, 2, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">num quidnam ad filium haec aegritudo attinet?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 1, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc quam ad rem dicam hoc attinere somnium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:1:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 3, 1, 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 1, 3, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quid istuc ad me attinet?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:3:3:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 3, 3, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quid id ad me attinet?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:4:2:136" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 4, 2, 136</bibl></cit>, and <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 3, 58</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod quidem ad nos duas attinuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:5:4:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 5, 4, 9</bibl></cit> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">comperiebam nihil ad Pamphilum quicquam attinere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 64</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 2, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Scin tu ... ad te attinere hanc Omnem rem?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:6:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 4, 6, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:1:2:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 1, 2, 54</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 1, 32</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 1, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:3:1:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 3, 1, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc nil ad nos de nobis attinet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:852" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 852</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:30" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 30</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vobis alio loco, ut se tota res habeat, quod ad eam civitatem attinet, demonstrabitur,</quote> <trans><tr>in respect to that city</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod ad me attinet,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ad Q. Fr. 2, 1</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 5, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:2 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 1, 2 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod ad provincias attineret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:26 al" default="NO" valid="yes">23, 26 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tamquam ad rem attineat quicquam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:2:27 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 2, 27 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed quid istae picturae ad me attinent?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:1:2:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 1, 2, 36</bibl></cit>: <hi rend="ital">Do.</hi> Hae quid ad me? <hi rend="ital">Tox.</hi> Immo ad te attinent: <cit><quote lang="la">et tuā refert,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:4:3:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pers. 4, 3, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tantumne ab re tuast oti tibi, Aliena ut cures eaque nil quae ad te attinent?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:1:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 1, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cetera quae ad colendam vitem attinebunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:14:38" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 4, 14, 38</bibl></cit>.—And with nunc = ad hoc tempus (eccl. Lat.): Quod nunc attinet, vade, <hi rend="ital">and for this time</hi> (Gr. <foreign lang="greek">to\ nu=n e)/xon</foreign>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:24:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Act. 24, 25</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4364.8" n="2" level="3"> Attinet (attinent) aliquem: neque quemquam attinebat<pb n="196" /> <cb n="ATTI" />  id recusare, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,001:chapter=19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Quinct. 19</bibl>: de magnitudine vocis nihil nos attinet commonere, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 3, 11, 20</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in his, quae custodiam religionis attinent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:1:1" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 1, 1</bibl></cit>, n. 14.—</sense><sense id="n4364.9" n="3" level="3"> Hoc attinet (haec attinent), and more freq. attinet with an <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi> as subject (<hi rend="ital">act.</hi> and <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi>), <hi rend="ital">it concerns</hi>, <hi rend="ital">it matters</hi>, <hi rend="ital">is of moment</hi>, <hi rend="ital">is of consequence</hi>, <hi rend="ital">is of importance</hi>: ea conquisiverunt, quae nihil attinebant, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 1, 1, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec patitur Scythas ... Parthum dicere, nec quae nihil attinent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:19:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 19, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de quo quid sentiam, nihil attinet dicere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:7:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 7, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil enim attinet quemquam nominari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:17:42" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 2, 17, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quia nec eosdem nominari adtinebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 23, 3, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec adtinuisse demi securim, cum sine provocatione creati essent, interpretabantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 36</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:41" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:23" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 23</bibl>; 6, 38; 34, 3; 36, 11; <cit><quote lang="la">37, 15: Quid attinet tot ora navium gravi Rostrata duci etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:4:17 al" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 4, 17 al.</bibl></cit>—And in pregn. signif., <hi rend="ital">it is serviceable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">useful</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">avails for</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">quid attinuit cum iis, quibuscum re concinebat, verbis discrepare?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:22:60" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 4, 22, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eā re non venit, quia nihil attinuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 12, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec victoribus mitti adtinere puto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 23, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sin (frumenta) protinus usui destinantur, nihil attinet repoliri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:21:6" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 2, 21, 6</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
attingo: <entryFree id="n4365" type="main" key="attingo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">at-tingo</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>), <itype>tĭgi, tactum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>tango</etym> (ante-class. form <orth extent="full" lang="la">attĭgo</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, <sense id="n4365.0" n="I" level="1"><xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">infra</ref></xr>; attinge = attingam, acc. to Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=26" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 26</bibl> Müll.; v. Müll. ad h. l.; concerning attigo, āre, v. <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>), <hi rend="ital">to touch</hi>, <hi rend="ital">come in contact with;</hi> constr. with the <hi rend="ital">acc.;</hi> <usg type="style">poet.</usg> with <hi rend="ital">ad.</hi> </sense><sense id="n4365.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n4365.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: mento summam aquam, vet. poët. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:5:10" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 5, 10</bibl>: vestem, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 75, 32</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Egone Argivum imperium attingam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 166</bibl></cit> Rib.: <cit><quote lang="la">suaviter (omnia) attingunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:623" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 623</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec enim ullum hoc frigidius flumen attigi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:3:6" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 3, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">prius quam aries murum attigisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedibus terram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:5:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Eum. 5, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quisquis (vas) attigerit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:15:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Lev. 15, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nos nihil tuorum attigimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:26:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Gen. 26, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(medicus) pulsum venarum attigit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">se esse possessorem soli, quod primum Divus Augustus nascens attigisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:5" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 5</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:4:3:46" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 4, 3, 46</bibl>: Tactaque nascenti corpus haberet humus, acc. to the practice of laying new-born children upon the ground; v. tollo).—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: (Callisto) miles erat Phoebes, nec Maenalon attigit (<hi rend="ital">nor did there touch</hi>, <hi rend="ital">set foot on</hi>) ulla Gratior hac Triviae, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:415" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 415</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">usque ad caelum attingebat stans in terrā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,033:18:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Sap. 18, 16</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4365.3" n="B" level="2"> With partic. access. ideas. </sense><sense id="n4365.4" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To touch</hi> by striking, <hi rend="ital">to strike;</hi> rarely in a hostile manner, <hi rend="ital">to attack</hi>, <hi rend="ital">assault</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne me attingas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:2:106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 2, 2, 106</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">ne attigas me,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Truc. 2, 2, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne attigas puerum istac caussā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:3:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 3, 3, 41</bibl></cit> (quoted by <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 75, 33</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">Si tu illam attigeris secus quam dignumst liberam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:3:91" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 2, 3, 91</bibl></cit>.—Of lightning: ICTV. FVLMINIS. ARBORES. ATTACTAE. ARDVERINT., Fragm. Fratr. Arval. <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 961</bibl>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Fest. s. v. scribonianum, p. 333 Müll., and s. v. obstitum, p. 193: si Vestinus attingeretur, i. e. ei bellum indiceretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 29</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:38" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 38</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4365.5" n="2" level="3"> In mal. part., aliquam, <hi rend="ital">to touch</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">virginem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:1:2:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 1, 2, 61</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:67:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 67, 20</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4365.6" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To touch</hi> in eating, <hi rend="ital">to taste</hi>, <hi rend="ital">crop</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nulla neque amnem Libavit quadrupes, nec graminis attigit herbam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:5:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 5, 26</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4365.7" n="4" level="3"> Of local relations, <hi rend="ital">to come to</hi> a place, <hi rend="ital">to approach</hi>, <hi rend="ital">reach</hi>, <hi rend="ital">arrive at</hi> (class.; <cit><quote lang="la">esp. freq. in the histt.): aedīs ne attigatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:2:2:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 2, 2, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut primum Asiam attigisti,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> ad Q. Fr. 1, 1, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum primis navibus Britanniam attigit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Siciliam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Dion, 5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dion, 5, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Syriam ac legiones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">saltuosos locos,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Urbem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 7 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">In paucis diebus quam Capreus attigit etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:60" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 60</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:44" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Calig. 44</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vesp.:4 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Vesp. 4 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n4365.8" n="5" level="3"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to touch</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lie near</hi>, <hi rend="ital">border upon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">be contiguous to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Theseus ... Attigit injusti regis Gortynia tecta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:64:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 64, 75</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cappadociae regio, quae Ciliciam attingeret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:15:4:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 15, 4, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 16 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">(stomachus) utrāque ex parte tonsillas attingens, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:54:135" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 54, 135</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eorum fines Nervii attingebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ITEM. COLLEGIA. QVAE. ATTINGVNT. EIDEM. FORO,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 3314</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">attingere parietem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,053:41:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Ezech. 41, 6</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n4365.9" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n4365.10" n="A" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to touch</hi>, <hi rend="ital">affect</hi>, <hi rend="ital">reach</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec desiderium nos attigit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:922" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 922</bibl></cit> (<hi rend="ital">adficit</hi>, <cb n="ATTI" /> Lachm.): <cit><quote lang="la">ante quam voluptas aut dolor attigerit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:5:16" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 3, 5, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nimirum me alia quoque causa delectat, quae te non attingit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:1:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 2, 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo studio providit, ne qua me illius temporis invidia attingeret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:10:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 10, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si qua de Pompeio nostro tuendo ... cura te attingit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 9, 11</bibl></cit>, A: <cit><quote lang="la">erant perpauci, quos ea infamia attingeret, Liv 27, 11, 6: cupidus attingere gaudia,</quote> <trans><tr>to feel</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:19:9" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 1, 19, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vox, sonus, attigit aures,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:2:452" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 2, 452</bibl></cit>; Claud. B. Get: 412; <bibl default="NO"><author>Manil.</author> 1, 326</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n4365.11" n="B" level="2"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n4365.12" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To touch upon in</hi> speaking, etc., <hi rend="ital">to mention slightly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">paucis rem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:4:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 4, 4, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">summatim attingere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:261" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 261</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut meos quoque attingam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:39:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 39, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod perquam breviter perstrinxi atque attigi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:49:201" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 49, 201</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 2, 4 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">si tantummodo summas attigero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Pelop. 1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Pelop. 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">invitus ea, tamquam vulnera, attingo, sed nisi tacta tractataque sanari non possunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut seditionem attigit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">familiae (Galbae) breviter attingam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:3 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Galb. 3 al.</bibl></cit> —</sense><sense id="n4365.13" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To touch</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to undertake</hi>, <hi rend="ital">enter upon</hi> some course of action (esp. mental), <hi rend="ital">to apply one's self to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">be occupied with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">engage in</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to take in hand</hi>, <hi rend="ital">manage</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae isti rhetores ne primoribus quidem labris attigissent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:19:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 19, 87</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:chapter=12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cael. 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:chapter=8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Arch. 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">egomet, qui sero ac leviter Graecas litteras attigissem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:18:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 18, 82</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">orationes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:13:41" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 13, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">poëticen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:18:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 18, 5</bibl></cit>;
